thread.title: Lundqvist: NYC’s Mets-mania not stopping Harvey from staying ‘focused’
thread.title_full: Lundqvist: NYC’s Mets-mania not stopping Harvey from staying ‘focused’ | New York Post

author: Larry Brooks
title: Lundqvist: NYC’s Mets-mania not stopping Harvey from staying ‘focused’
text:
So a King and a Dark Knight walk into the weight room adjacent to the Rangers’ locker room at the Garden after a game, and …
And Henrik Lundqvist and his friend Matt Harvey, who received an ovation when introduced on the video board midway through the second period of Thursday’s 4-1 Blueshirts’ victory over the Coyotes, have a chat.
“Obviously he’s excited and I’m very happy for him with the way he’s been able to stay focused through all of this,” Lundqvist said of the newly minted National League pennant winner. “This is a crazy city when a sports team makes it to the final.
“As another New Yorker, you always appreciate the success of a sports team in this city,” said Lundqvist, who of course led his team to the 2014 Stanley Cup final, albeit a five-game loss to the Kings.
This was the first Rangers game of the year for Harvey, an avid fan who had been otherwise occupied with pitching business for the Mets, who will play Game 1 of the World Series on Tuesday in either Kansas City or Toronto.
Anthony Duclair used one word to describe his state of mind upon learning that he had been traded by the Rangers to the Coyotes last March 1 as part of the pricey package that brought Keith Yandle to Broadway.
“Shock,” the Duke of the Desert said before the match. “I wasn’t angry, I wasn’t happy, it was just a big shock for me.
“When you’re a young guy, you don’t expect to be traded so early in your career,” Duclair said. “I didn’t see it coming, there weren’t any rumors or anything.
“I found out after the second period of one of my junior games. It was strange.”
When previously last seen at the Garden, Duclair had been in street clothes, a healthy scratch for the Blueshirts for the club’s Dec. 8 overtime victory over the Penguins. That marked his third straight game out of the lineup after having played in 17 of the Rangers’ first 23 matches.
The following day, Dec. 9, Duclair was loaned to Team Canada for the World Junior Tournament, after which the winger returned to his QMJHL Quebec Remparts for the remainder of the season.
“When I went back to juniors I thought I’d be coming back here this year,” said Duclair, who has five goals and two assists in seven games. “Like I said, I was really shocked by the trade. But I’m happy now. It’s a great fit for me.”
There is no bitterness. Why should there be?
“I had a great time in New York; getting to play with guys I looked up to like Marty St. Louis, Rick Nash and Henrik Lundqvist—St. Louis, especially—was an honor for me,” said Duclair, robbed by Lundqvist on an acrobatic stop with 4:50 to go and the score 3-1. “And being here for the start of last year gave me more confidence coming into this training camp.
“It was tough for me to be in and out of the lineup [in New York] but I understood the situation,” he said. “Here, I’m getting to play. I couldn’t be happier.”
